basics.name: Mohamed Habib Ben Abda
basics.label: Electrical Engineering & Information Technology Student
basics.summary: Specializing in embedded systems, sensor electronics, and firmware for wearables and medical devices. Experienced in creating low-noise acquisition circuits, developing human–machine interfaces, and integrating hardware–software systems for robust signal aquisition and processing.

work.name: Real World Robotics ETH
highlights: Delivered a workshop and project-based assignments for a robotics course, mentoring 30 students on sensing technologies in robotic hands.

work.name: Johnson & Johnson MedTech
highlights: Automated optical tracking accuracy assessment for spine surgery robot extensions, using C++, reducing validation time by 90%, and supporting pre-market verification workflows.
Assisted in various electrical/mechanical engineering tasks such as CTQ (Critical To Quality) definition, IEC 60601 assessment, DFM (Design For Manufacturing) and S&R improvements.

work.name: Chipiron
highlights: Prototyped and tested a mixed-signal control system for MRI magnetic-field stabilization using a microcontroller and PID loop; worked with precision, low-noise analog front-ends under strong EMI constraints.
Designed, simulated, and validated a cryogenic low-noise filter for a high-precision magnetic sensor, improving signal integrity through EMI reduction and impedance-optimized filtering.

work.name: Biosensors Lab @ UIUC
highlights: Programmed an FPGA in Verilog to control biomedical camera lens focus for cancer cell detection during surgery and coded in Python to control testing instruments.

work.name: EPFL
highlights: Tutored groups of 10–40 students during weekly exercise sessions in the following courses: Electronics, General Physics, Thermodynamics, Analytical Geometry

work.name: EPFL Spacecraft Team
highlights: Led a 2.7M CHF space mission to send the first student-led Swiss constellation of cube-satellites, managing interdisciplinary sub-teams to meet deadlines and ensure seamless collaboration.
Pioneered and guided a major organizational strategy shift and persuaded 10+ university and industry partners to support this new vision.
Optimized the satellite's power budget and operation schedule using MATLAB orbit simulations.

courses: Focus: Embedded Systems, Signal Processing, Electronics

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
